addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghely Lord highe Treasurer of England

20 Au
g
1592. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.178r
Upon
e closing of my former, I receaved her
Hig
nes
letter to
e
states
of
e 2 of this moneth,
and yo
r
L. to my self, of
e self same date. I hope
yo
r
L. is resolved,
at in as muche as I am able,
there hath wanted no endevo
r
, to give good order
for
e companies. They have bin in garrison more
then a moneth, and are still in a readines, to
marche, when they are sent for. For I have al-
waies bin persuaded, as I have formerly signified,
that
e states will give no leave, howsoever
they shall be urged, but yet I stand not
in
doubt
of any publicke impeachement. And therfor
whensoever her Ma
tie
shall send I will accomplishe
for my self, what is possible for me, and I knowe
S
r
Francis Vere
will be wanting to nothing.
Upon
e deliverie of this letter of her Ma
tie
and
my instance unto them, to receave their present
answear, they have signified unto me,
at they
have sent expressely to
Count Maurice
, to
e Coun-
cel of state, and to
e Deputies of
e Provinces,
that are at
e Campe, to demaunde their advise,
w
ch
being understoode, they will take some final
resolution, and impart it unto me. I have
answeared againe
at for mine owne part I
doe expect every houre, to be commaunded by her
Hig
nes
to cause
e companies to be shipped: w
ch
charge comming to me, I might not attend w
at
they would resolve: and therfor wished them
to thinke upon a speedier course of dealing.
Of
e strength of
e companies that were in
e
field w
t
S
r
Francis Vere, I thinke yo
r
L. by this
is perfitly informed. For
M
r
Allen
e C
o
missary
fol.178v
20 Au
g
92
of
e musters hath sent a man of purpose, to de-
liver his bookes to
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
. I will s
e
d
to S
r
Francis out of hand, and signifie of all
at
yo
r
L. hath written. What hath
moved
e states to send for
M
r
Caron
, I can not
certifie assuredly, nor he is not yet come hither.
But to shewe yo
r
L. my conjecture, it is a good
while sins
at I have heard, that they have greatly
disliked of his folowing of their buisnes, for
at
they thought, as hath bin saied,
at he was par-
tially inclined to proceede in their affaires to
her Ma
ties
best liking. And therfore whether it
be to revoke him cleane, or to instruct him other-
wise, or for some other cause, I will learne if I
can, and lett yo
r
L. understand it.
And so
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Au
g
20 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
